It wasn't until the late 1970s that the Subway got major investment. This didn't involve expanding the original circle, but everything was ripped out and replaced. You can see more about that here in this film produced by the Greater Glasgow PTE: https://t.co/frS0a1yI6s

There were two major expansions mooted in the early years of public ownership. One was a line from Robroyston to Kings Park (we can but dream, southsiders). The other was a second circle that would have served the East End. But neither came off.

In this era the Subway had - apart from being re-named the Underground in the 1930s - few changes. Maintenance workers, salvaged old tram cars for spare parts. Francie and Josie's comic song rather sums up the affectionate humour that surrounded it: https://t.co/v1GekH96uT
In 1935 the cable traction was replaced with electric motors. BUT rather than ordering new rolling stock the old 1896 carriages were retrofitted, and stayed in service until (!) the late 1970s.

Negotiations began for a Glasgow Corporation (council) buyout. But directors rejected the city‚Äôs ¬£300,000 offer, demanding half a million instead. They eventually settled for ¬£385,000 - but in the meantime the Subway had faced a closure of several months.

The privately-owned Subway was struggling financially by the early 1920s, with lenders reluctant to offer their services to railways following bad experiences with the London Tube. Passenger numbers were down too. Directors initially offered personal guarantees.

In early 1920 Subway workers won a significant pay rise after a lengthy strike. Bosses had originally hoped there would be a sufficient number of strikebreakers to keep one circle going - but the strike was widely observed and the whole thing was shut down.

The Subway didn‚Äôt reopen until 21 January 1897. But passenger numbers grew substantially in its first few decades, particularly given Glasgow‚Äôs role as an industrial centre in the build up to and during WW1.

By mid-afternoon the outer circle was out of action following a ‚Äúcable jump‚Äù (the trains were originally cable hauled).
